segments.text: This is an interview with Eloy Rodriguez by Jaime Rodriguez on November 20, 1990, at Thomas Jefferson Junior High School, Beagle, Texas, concerning the Vietnam War.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I'm asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M oral history collection in the university archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, it's all right.
Please state your name.
It's Eloy Rodriguez.
And your date of birth?
October the 3rd, 1945.
Okay, where did you grow up?
I grew up in Beaver, Texas.
What made you decide to join the Marines?
Well, at that time, Jaime, the draft was in effect, and if you weren't in school and you were of age, you were being drafted.
At the time, I was working in Los Angeles, California, and I got my draft notice in Texas, so I saw that as a way to get back home.
as an excuse to get back home.
So I came back and I was going to get drafted.
So what I did, I went ahead and enlisted in the Marine Corps under the lay program.
So I enlisted in January, but I didn't go in until late for the 14th.
How long were you in the Marines before you went to Vietnam?
My first day of boot camp was April the 14th, 1966.
And going back to your previous question, I joined the Marine Corps because everyone was joining the Marine Corps, all my friends.
And if you didn't join the Marine Corps, you weren't really too popular with the other guys.
That's the reason I jumped.
But I was in the Marine Corps.
Boot camp was April the 14th, 1966.
I took my basic training in San Diego.
Then I went to Camp Pelton, California.
After that, I went to Camp Lejeune, North Carolina.
We did a tour in Puerto Rico for a couple of months.
Then I came back, and I had my orders from Vietnam in August of 1967.
When you first went to the war, did you feel that the war was winnable?
Well, to be honest with you, Jaime, I didn't know that much about what was going on.
All I knew was that we had a lot of men over there.
I knew we had a war.
I knew that if you went in the Marine Corps and you didn't go to Vietnam, that you weren't really a Marine until you went over there.
As far as whether the war was winnable or not, I assumed that it was.
What they were telling us was that it would be a matter of months before we came back, that we would win this thing at any time.
So I went over there on a 13-month tour, but expecting to come back any time before.
You said you were stationed at different locations.
around the United States, but when you went to Vietnam, where were you stationed?
I was at Camp Lejeune, North Carolina.
I got there about the middle of January of 67, and I was there until August of 67 with a little tour to Puerto Rico.
What were your job descriptions in the Marines?
When I graduated from boot camp, my MOS, which is what you do in the military,
2533, that's a radio telegraph operator.
I went to school for approximately four months in San Diego.
But once I left school, I didn't see the telegraph team anymore.
I went to June, Camp of June, and I became a radio operator, which is 2531.
When I got to Vietnam, I was a radio operator for an infantry company, 2531.
But I also became a wireman, which I think was a 2511.
I became a murder man, which was in 03-41, I believe.
I also served as a rifleman, which was in 03-11.
So I had various MOSs.
I picked them up, OJT, they called them, on the job training.
During the time of combat, what was the morale like of the soldiers?
Well, it's difficult to say.
When you're over here in the States, boy, you just can't wait to go over there to serve your country and do what the other Marines are doing.
Again, you can call yourself a true Marine unless you went over there.
But as time got closer to go to Vietnam, you start getting a little shaky and not knowing what to expect.
For whatever reasons, I felt that I was going to be a telegraph operator.
And I got over there.
They were up front with me as a radio operator.
So my morale when I got over there, I was scared.
But as I went to my base camp, I saw that other guys were there.
And I was scared because of the unknown.
I didn't know what to expect.
The morale was good in the rear when I first got there.
But once you go out on patrols and things of this nature,
You, even as a young man, you start thinking of other things.
The people back home, girlfriend, parents, what are people doing back in America?
You are 19, 20 years old.
You don't know if you're going to come back.
You're a lot more careful now.
You're much more mature beyond your years as far as thinking ahead again about your families.
You are a lot more careful.
You listen to the guys who have been there before.
You do what they ask you to do, because they're the ones who know.
They're the ones who have been there.
So again, I was there in the early part of it.
I was there in 67, 68, which was a lot different from 70, 71, 72.
So the morale, I feel, was high.
We believed what they told us.
We felt that we had a purpose to be over there.
We felt that we were doing the right thing.
What were your personal feelings toward Arvin?
Well, again, Jaime, when I got there, the word was that don't trust the Arvins.
They don't want to fight.
They'll go out with you, and if the action gets too heavy, they're going to retreat on their own.
They're not good at following instructions.
Personally, I didn't like them.
because of what I had heard and the little I saw.
I couldn't trust them.
The other people that were around me wouldn't trust them.
They had a way about them that was very untrustworthy.
It seemed like they were out to get whatever they could get from you, whether it was food or money or weapons or whatever.
I didn't like them.
I didn't trust them.
I didn't know what they were up to.
How was the racism situation as far as the U.S. military and the Vietnamese people, or any kind of racism?
Well, we felt that they weren't our equal.
We felt that we were there to help them, and they should be grateful for that.
We treated them as second-class citizens.
To us, they weren't up to par with us.
And I think they felt, some of them felt the same way about us.
I still remember going through a village, and there was maybe about 100 little kids, six, seven, eight-year-olds.
And someone took a camera and took their pictures, and every single one of those kids shot us the finger.
So at that time, this was like in October of 67, things went through my mind.
I said, well, we're here to help them.
But now I see this.
I don't know what's going on.
Once you got back into the States, was it hard to get back into the American swing of things?
Well, in a way, yes, and in a way, no, Jaime.
I remember when we went over there, we went through all kinds of counseling sessions, being nice to their people, with their guests, do this, do that.
We'd come back, and no one tells us how the,
how the world is going to react to us, especially the United States.
They don't tell us what's been going on here for the last year.
And when you're over there, especially when you're in the rear, you talk about home.
You talk about when you come back, oh, I'm going to school, I'm getting married, I'm going to do this, I'm going to do that.
And when you come back, you do all those things.
Sometimes you try and get everything in
as quickly as possible.
You want to get married.
You want to get a job.
You want to get back to school.
And there's changes.
Really, when I came back, I just wanted to do all those things we talked about.
And now I feel that maybe I was too quick in doing some of those things.
What were some of the strategies that the United States used to try to win this war?

Well, the bombing, bombing of the North, the bombing of the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the what's it called, the Agent Orange, what they call the Vietnamization of the countryside, where we were sent out people to work with the farmers, with the small villages, and trying to win them over.
Those are the ones I remember at this time.
I'm sure there was a lot of others.
But I don't think it helped.
If anything, it was the bombing of the North.
That might have been effective.
But as far as Vietnamizing the countryside and the villages, no.
They would go to the person who was there last.
If we were there, they were on our side.
And the Arvins, which is the
Army of the Republic of Vietnam.
I'm sorry, the NVA, the North Vietnamese Army.
When they were there, well, they had control.
So I don't feel any in-country.
By that, I mean South Vietnam.
Anything we did in South Vietnam, it didn't seem to work.
OK. As far as the search and destroy strategy went, did you feel that was an effective strategy in episode one?
Well, not really, because we searched and we destroyed.
It wasn't really because what it did, it made a lot of enemies.
You're talking about people who have been there for generations and generations, parents, grandparents, great-grandparents.
They all came from that village, and here comes these big American soldiers, and they're burning it down, they're relocating you.
You're having to start all over.
I don't think it was effective in that sense.
Whatever we destroyed, it was replaced by the...
by the Viet Cong or the NBA.
So I feel that it wasn't effective.
Did you personally agree with this war?
Again, I was there in the early part of the war.
This thing started, I think, in March of 65.
And when I got there in September of 67, it was still popular.
Most of the United States felt we were doing the right thing.
So I felt good about going over there, again, because of what they told us, what you heard.
And that's the reason we said those things, because that's all they told us.
Again, the early part of the war, we felt that we were doing good.
And as things turned out, because of the lack of support and what I've heard say, because of a few vocal minority, we were forced to do a lot of things.
Instead of going all out and trying to win this war.
Because even if we did, we might have not won it.
OK. Once the war started getting towards the end and the American people started feeling that it was not going to be a winnable war, there was a bunch of anti-war protests.
What were your feelings on that?
Well, at that time and until very recently, I really hated it.
And I guess, in a sense, I still do.
Here you were.
putting your life on the line.
That was the fact that many young Americans died because they were defending the same rights that I feel these people were abusing by protesting the war.
Again, that was another thing that happened that forced our people in Washington to turn their back on us in a way where they were beginning to listen to the voters
or to the people who were protesting.
And the war, it wasn't a standstill, but there was so much conflict with people
for and against the war, that this thing, it seemed like the North Vietnamese purposely let it run more because they could see what was happening in the United States.
It was a split United States.
And the ones that were really being hurt were the people who were over there.
Well, again, by the end of the war, the United States people started thinking it wasn't worth it.
and all this news was getting back to the soldiers, did the morale change at all?
Well, it did change.
Again, I was there earlier, and it had to have changed, because those guys were here when all this was going on.
They didn't get over there until 70, 71, 72.
So they saw all of this before they left.
They knew that a lot of America was against this war.
And again, it was two different wars, 65 to probably the end of 68, early 69.
You had the people who wanted to be over there, about 80.
And this is, I'm just guesstimating, about 80% of the people from 65 to early, early 69 wanted to be there.
But after that, you started getting all the draftees from the middle of 69 on till the war was over.
A lot of those guys over there were draftees who didn't want to be over there.
So the attitude was different.
They knew that.
that people in America weren't supporting, so they didn't want to get killed or whatever.
It seemed like a lost cause to them.
Hey, did the combat refusals become a problem?
Not when I was there, especially in the Marine Corps.
I don't know how the Army reacted, but the Marine Corps, I feel, is a very elite group.
Whether you're a... you can't...
Say, I'm not going.
There's just too many people against you.
So that never, to us, again in 67, 68, that never crossed our minds.
There was times we didn't want to go.
There's no way we were going to say no, because we were going to go anyway.
No one was going to let us stay behind.
So we were going to go one way or the other.
So we never said no.
I know towards the latter part of the war, there was a lot of that.
Maybe it was with reason.
I don't know if I would have been in the Army in 1972, and I might have refused, yes.
Could you describe a typical day during the war?
Well, it all depended on what you were doing that day.
If you were in the rear, it was a lot more work.
There was more people watching you.
Maybe you had...
kitchen work to do, maybe you had radio watches during the day, you wrote letters.
If you were getting ready to go out, well, then that's when you wrote your personal letters to your girlfriend, wives, parents, telling them you were going to go out and be back in maybe a week.
So if they don't hear from you, that's why.
I was on a hospital ship, the USS Princeton.
And we usually would go back for a day or two, take a shower, eat a meal, and we knew we were going out.
It was called a BLT, Battalion Landing Team.
What we did, we cruised the coast of South Vietnam.
We did this for a couple of months.
And whenever someone got in trouble, the helicopters would take us out.
And it's kind of an empty feeling.
It's like you don't know where you're going or what's going to happen.
It's kind of a quiet moment for everyone.
You just sit there and get your thoughts together and go out and do your job.
Once you got back, how did the people treat you?
Well, the majority of them... Well, let me restate that.
The majority of my friends welcomed me back.
They were glad I was back.
They were glad...
that I came back in one piece.
It's people that you didn't know.
I enrolled at Bee County College, and there was a couple of instructors there who kind of didn't make you feel comfortable because they seemed like they were against the war.
I remember in speech,
I gave a presentation on the war.
And the guy, I thought it was at least a C, of course.
But it seemed like the guy just wasn't too gung ho about what was happening over there.
So I received a D. So from people I didn't know, it just wasn't the same.
It got to where anyone who you didn't know, you wouldn't talk to them about Vietnam.
Okay, now I realize that this may be a touchy subject, but did you kill anyone during combat?
And if so, how are you coping with it now?
Well, we killed quite a few people.
I was a caisson, a battle of caisson from the middle of January to late April.
I'm sorry, late March, early April.
And as a unit, we had, I think the estimates are, I think, over 15,000.
my own company.
I know we're responsible for quite a few.
We try to overrun us one night.
We put mortars on a lot of them.
I don't know how many we killed.
As far as it bothered me, I try never, never to think about things like that.
It's just something that it's kind of a deep secret, something that you did that you don't want to tell anyone.
I don't even like to
to remember any details of it.
Somehow, for some reason, I just refuse to remember the details about our killing.
I do remember, in a lot of detail, our men that were killed.
That's because someone you were with all the time.
And yes, our unit killed a lot of North Vietnamese.
OK. Well, that's all the questions I have.
I'd like to thank you for taking time and participating in this interview.
And that's it.
Thank you very much, Hank.
